utterances: Well, after a year of preparation, working out, improving your memory, you go to the U.S.
Memory Championships, what was it like?
Well, a memory contest is a bit like the SATs.
It's a lot of people sitting around at desks scribbling away answers furiously and then handing them in at the front of the room.
It's not quite as sexy as a spelling bee, but it's definitely got its drama.
(Soundbite of laughter)
The common mistakes are the simple mistakes.
People make math errors, people transcribe their Social Security wrong, people don't sign the check that they send to the government.
The best thing people can do is electronically file a return.
Therefore, they'll be using software, they will have the math done for them, it'll double check to make sure all the information is there.
The information will get to us, will get straight into our computers.
And if you're getting a refund, like most Americans do, that refund will come to you quicker.
And I'm just beginning to worry about - I sensed a couple of certified envelopes offered later today and I'm wondering if I got the right check or the right envelope.
Oh, yes, that's another common thing.
By the way, IRS has what they call the Free File Alliance.
You can find it on their Web site.
And that they figure that more than 80 percent of the population that files can actually get their returns done free electronically using the members of the Free File Alliance.
So, you know, you may want to try that.
And if you go to the Free File Alliance Web site, you can probably even get your extension filed online for free and get the electronic receipt.
So, again, that's just available to anybody for free as the Web site?
Yeah.
And, you know, some people may not qualify.
There are probably about 15 members of the Free File Alliance.
They have different income levels.
I think there's an income level of about 56,000 on the general Free File Alliance.
But if you pass through that a little bit, IRS has their own forms that you can file - fill in and file directly.
And I think they said they're running that through Intuit, through TurboTax's system.
But anybody at all can use that.
Now, the only thing is that doesn't come with the state return.
That's just the IRS.
Ah, forgetting that state return.
That can be a problem.
Yeah.
That's another thing, Neal.
People who are working in several areas, they get W-2s or 1099s, or even K-1s for their investments from different states, forget to file in the other states.
And sometimes, even though you don't owe them money, it will make a difference later on when you start selling that investment and having a profit.
You won't have the record of all the losses in that state.
Worthwhile filing those returns in those states.
I just wanted to check up - following up on what the commissioner said.
Do you agree with him, filing electronically is a good idea?
Oh, God, yes.
Oh, absolutely.
Yeah, you don't have the math errors.
If you transpose the Social Security number, your return is going to get rejected so you can fix it.
The other thing that happens when you file electronically is - believe it or not, a lot of people are having their refunds grabbed by IRS, which is the master collection agency for the country.
They'll collect for states, for Social Security and student loans.
You're going to get a code and information when you file electronically that tells you if IRS is going to grab all or part of your refund.
Let's get some callers in on the conversation.
We're talking with Eva Rosenberg, who's an enrolled agent and founder of TaxMama.com, and author of the new e-book, ""100% Home-Based Business Solution."" And she's with us today from California.
800-989-8255, email: talk@npr.org.
Give us the benefit of the painful lessons you've learned from your dealings with the IRS.
Let's talk with Nicole(ph).
Nicole, calling us from Boise.
Hi, Neal.
I love your show, by the way.
Thanks very much.
We just discovered this mistake last night, and maybe your expert can tell me what's going to happen.
We went to file our state taxes because we're owing them money and we are getting a refund from the federal, so we're going to use the federal to pay the state.
So I went to go do the state last night, and my husband discovered things had been put in the wrong envelopes.
We put the federal in the state envelope and vice versa.
So I redid everything last night and put a big note, and he was just worried that we were going to be penalized.
And luckily, it hasn't been the 15th yet, but he just came undone.
It was that awful feeling of a hole opening in the pit of your stomach.
Yeah.
He - well, luckily, we had it all saved.
We did TurboTax, although we did need to automatically file.
But I'm wondering - I'm assuming it'll all be okay because we got the check in the mail in enough time, but I'm wondering if your expert can tell me, are we in trouble.
Eva, is she going to be filing her next return from Leavenworth?
Could be, but I don't think so.
I'm not clear.
Did you actually fix it and mail the check to the state in the - ultimately - okay.
If you mailed it to the state, they'll get it.
If you sent them two checks because the first one was an IRS thing, not a problem.
If you sent the state check to IRS, they're automatically going to deposit it, so make sure you follow up and get that money back.
Okay.
Good luck, Nicole.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Let's see if we can go now to Melissa(ph).
Melissa, with us from Birmingham, Alabama.
Hi.
Hi, there.
Hey.
Yeah.
So, I have never dealt with my taxes before, ever, like not even my own personal ones.
I just graduated college with a communications degree, got a job as an accounting assistant, and had to do a lot of the tax filing this year.
I've never been so terrified in my entire life.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I didn't know what (unintelligible)…
And your question is?
Yes.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Oh, no. They were just asking for stories.

I was going to say, I was never so scared - I put in the name of the company wrong and so we had to redo the whole thing, because the legal name was in the wrong - and we were scared it was going to end up getting a big thing.
Would it have been a big thing?
We just - I just…
You mistyped the company name, so like Brown and Smith, and you add an extra E to Brown or…
Yes.
You know…
It was sort of basically that kind of a thing.
I'm sure that your boss was upset, and it made his company not look as good on the printed returns - doesn't matter to IRS.
IRS cross references by the employer ID number at the bottom of the tax return.
There are two numbers there, one is the preparer's ID number, which is either a PTIN number or their social security number and the other is the firm's ID number.
Those are the only two things that matter to IRS.
They don't really care about the name.
Well, okay, I didn't screw up as bad as I thought I did.
Okay.
You're good.
